abstract.p: Rectal trauma is associated with high rates of morbidity and mortality and generally affects young males due to its aetiology of violent crime and vehicular collision. Historically, management has followed principles derived from military practice, with faecal diversion, pre-sacral drainage and distal washout being mandatory. Civilian trauma studies examining management of colon and rectum injuries from the early 1950s identified major differences in the level of energy transfer between civilian and military wounds, given that the vast majority are penetrating in nature. This led to a re-evaluation of the necessity for these interventions for all rectal injuries. Current management depends on whether the injury is intra- or extraperitoneal, with those above the peritoneal reflection being readily accessible and amenable to treatment as for colon injury. Extraperitoneal injuries remain difficult to access and direct repair is usually impossible; the mainstay of treatment in most instances remains faecal diversion. The role of pre-sacral drainage and distal washout remains contentious in the realms of civilian rectal injury but retains a place in battlefield or other high-energy transfer rectal injuries where aggressive early management reduces septic complications. This article reviews the historical and current evidence for the management of both civilian and military extraperitoneal rectal injuries.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Rectal trauma is relatively uncommon and is usually associated with high-energy transfer injury; this article examines the evidence regarding its epidemiology, aetiology and management. The commonest cause of anorectal trauma, in the United Kingdom at least (Thakar and Sultan, 2003), is obstetric injury and is a significant topic in its own right (Fernando et al., 2002) and is not discussed in this article. Likewise, colonic trauma is not specifically reviewed as several excellent reviews exist (Amin and Rowlands, 2000; Cleary et al., 2006; Maxwell and Fabian, 2003), although it is pertinent that some of the evidence for the management of rectal trauma comes from papers on colorectal trauma and where possible the rectal injury data is extracted separately.

Over the last century it has been battlefield colorectal injury that has provided the principles of management that have subsequently been adopted, and then adapted, into the care of civilian injuries. During World War 1, British surgeons instituted pelvic debridement and drainage for rectal wounds; this approach reduced the mortality of penetrating rectal injuries from the historical norm of 90% in the American Civil War to 70% (Fraser and Drummond, 1917; Wallace, 1917). At the outset of World War 2, this fell further to 36% when Ogilvie (1944) added defunctioning colostomy to this treatment scheme. The success of this approach led to the US Surgeon General mandating retrorectal drainage (Office of the Surgeon General of the Army, 1943) (via coccygectomy or paracoccygeal incision) and proximal colostomy for all rectal wounds and mortality fell to as low as 6% in some series by the end of the war (Taylor and Thompson, 1948).

As the differences in levels of energy transfer between military and civilian injuries were recognised, trials of less invasive management reported good results in civilian rectal injury (treated by primary rectal wound closure alone) although there was a mortality rate of greater than 20% in these studies (Gumbert et al., 1996; Trunkey et al., 1973; Vannix et al., 1963). By the time of the Vietnam War, the military caveats of drainage and diversion were reinstated and distal rectal washout added as well as debridement and direct repair if feasible (Armstrong et al., 1973; Ganchrow et al., 1970; Lavenson and Cohen, 1971) – mortality rates for these high-energy transfer injuries was 17% (Lavenson and Cohen, 1971).

sec.title: Anatomy
sec.p: The rectum is the continuation of the sigmoid colon and begins where the colonic taenia coli coalesce into a complete longitudinal muscle layer. It is covered by peritoneum anteriorly and laterally in its upper third, anteriorly in its middle third and is extraperitoneal in the lower third. The rectum is encased in a layer of connective tissue and fat called the mesorectum which is wider behind than in front of the rectum and contains the neurovascular supply. The rectum is closely related to the bladder, prostate and seminal vesicles anteriorly beyond Denonvilliers fascia, the structures of the pelvic side walls (ureters and iliac vessels) laterally and the superior rectal artery and sacrum and coccyx posteriorly behind Waldeyers fascia in the male. The Pouch of Douglas and uterus lies anteriorly in the female.

sec.title: Penetrating injury
sec.p: Penetrating trauma accounts for 80% of rectal trauma (Merlino and Reynolds, 2004) with gunshot wounds (GSWs) in the majority although the exact proportions of GSWs to stab wounds and impalements is dependent on the geographical area of the individual studies (Marti et al., 1986; Shatnawi and Bani-Hani, 2006; Stokes and Jones, 1992). Gunshot wounds in particular are associated with a high concomitant injury burden with between 1.26 and 4.5 other injuries per rectal injury (Merlino and Reynolds, 2004). The most commonly injured other viscera is the urinary bladder (Franko et al., 1993). Partial thickness injury may occur in up to 30% of penetrating injuries (Morken et al., 1999).

Within the narrow confines of the pelvis, low energy transfer wounds will damage structures in the path of the missile whereas in high-energy transfer the effects of cavitation must also be considered. Transpelvic gunshot trauma poses a high risk of injury to the rectum and other organs with rectal injuries reported in 40% of such patients in a civilian study (Navsaria et al., 2011) matched by Arthurs’ 2006 report of transpelvic battlefield GSWs requiring damage control surgery in which 43% suffered extraperitoneal rectal injury (Arthurs et al., 2006).

sec.title: Blunt injury
sec.p: Blunt rectal injury is much more uncommon than penetrating injury and Merlino and Reynolds (2004) review of 39 studies yielded a 6.2% incidence, one third of which were from motor vehicle collisions (MVCs). Extraperitoneal injury occurs by shearing at the anorectal junction where the bowel is relatively fixed (Nolan, 1990).

sec.title: Blast injury
sec.p: Civilian blast trauma of any description is uncommon, although industrial and terrorist explosions do occur and worldwide, 2000 civilians are still killed each month by residual landmines (Horrocks, 2001); primary blast injuries of the rectum have not been reported (Owers et al., 2010). Secondary blast injury, i.e. penetration by fragments, has been described by Israeli authors, with two cases of penetrating rectal injury occurring in 146 victims of a single terrorist incident (Almogy et al., 2002).

sec.title: Foreign body injury
sec.p: “The variety of foreign bodies retrieved from the rectum shows that the only limitation is the capacity of the rectum and certainly not the human imagination” said Haft and Benjamin (1973),who studied the psychology of inserting foreign bodies into one’s rectum. It is a well recognised, but almost certainly under-reported, phenomenon and can lead to rectal perforation (Clarke et al., 2005; Lo et al., 2004; Losanoff and Kjossev, 1999) – embarrassment may lead to delayed presentation (Kann and Hicks, 2004).

Kurer et al. (2010) performed a systematic review of the management of rectal foreign bodies which encompassed 196 insertions. The majority of patients are male, with ages ranging from 16 to 79 years. The commonest reason was for sexual gratification, with one quarter inserted for personal hygiene reasons and relief of pruritus ani or constipation. Accidents and sexual assaults also contribute to the numbers (Clarke et al., 2005; Ikeda et al., 1991) as well as insertion secondary to pyschoses and drink-related betting (Caliskan et al., 2011; Kurer et al., 2010).

Cases of full thickness perforation with or without peritonitis do occur (Barone et al., 1976; Clarke et al., 2005), occasionally with a fatal outcome (Waraich et al., 2007), but the majority of rectal foreign body insertions cause mucosal injury only (Lake et al., 2004).

Anal fisting injuries represent a specific subgroup of rectal insertion injury and are more likely to cause full thickness injury. Cohen et al. (2004) reported three HIV-positive gay men who sustained perforative injury of the sigmoid, rectosigmoid and rectum, respectively, after anal fisting. All three cases recovered, two with stomas whereas Orr et al. (1995) reported a series of fatal fisting injuries including two adult women who succumbed after rectal perforation following sexual assault.

sec.title: Iatrogenic injury
sec.p: Iatrogenic rectal injury is rare, accounting for about 2.5% of cases (Merlino and Reynolds, 2004), but can range from minor mucosal tears to full thickness injury. Although colonic perforation from endoscopic procedures is well reported and the risk well quantified (Iqbal et al., 2008), there is little data for rectal injury. Quallick and Brown (2009) reported four rectal perforations in nearly 40,000 colonoscopies, attributed to retroflexion in the rectum as well as other sporadic case reports (Katsinelos et al., 2009).

The incidence of rectal perforation following barium enema studies ranges from 0.002 to 0.23% and carries a mortality of up to 50% because of the toxic effect of the extravasated barium. Most injuries are caused by direct catheter trauma, but pre-existing mucosal damage and over-distension of the lumen may also contribute (de Feiter et al., 2006).

Rectal injury sustained during other pelvic surgery is rare; during laparoscopic radical prostatectomy the rate is approximately 1–2%, with the majority recognised and managed intra-operatively (Blumberg et al., 2009; Katz et al., 2003). There is also a report of rectal perforation by Kirschner wires during fixation of a proximal hip fracture (Khallaf et al., 2002).

sec.title: Fracture-related injury
sec.p: Rectal injury associated with open pelvic fracture has an incidence of 18–64% with the wide variance probably in part due to the small sample sizes of the papers studied, and the presence of a rectal injury increases the risk of mortality and morbidity (Grotz et al., 2005). The risk of sustaining a rectal injury is significantly increased in patients with pubic symphysis diastasis or sacroiliac joint fractures (Aihara et al., 2002).

sec.title: Military injury
sec.p: Published reports of military rectal injury are less common than civilian, but the incidence of rectal injury is often higher in military trauma (Duncan et al., 2008; Stankovic et al., 1996; Steele et al., 2007), due to the higher energy transfer wounding mechanisms. Out of 23 patients evacuated with a colorectal injury during a 20-month period of American military activity in Iraq, 3 (13%) suffered a rectal injury (Duncan et al., 2008), whereas data from an in-theatre Field Hospital described 175 colorectal injuries out of 3442 trauma patients treated over 15 months, 26 of which were extraperitoneal rectal injuries (0.75% of total trauma workload) (Steele et al., 2007). Reports tend to describe a penetrating mechanism of injury with 96% of Steele et al.’s (2007) cohort injured by this mechanism. Military colorectal injury in general usually results from higher energy transfer than civilian injury, leading to more widespread tissue and organ damage (Merlino and Reynolds, 2004),but only rectal and transverse colon injuries were independently associated with an increased risk of mortality (Steele et al., 2007).

It is widely accepted that the pattern of injury now being seen in the military campaign in Afghanistan is different to that seen and reported previously. Improvised explosive devices (IEDs) now predominate producing a signature injury pattern of high bilateral lower limb amputations and significant perineal injury with potentially devastating anorectal injury (Parker, 2011); to date published reports are absent.

sec.title: Epidemiology
sec.p:
According to large trauma databases, rectal injury, either alone or combined with colonic injury, is uncommon with a 1.1% incidence of colorectal injury in 16,814 blunt trauma patients (Ricciardi et al., 2004) of which less than one tenth were rectal. Two further reports suggested rectal injury incidences of 0.27% (Vitale et al., 1983) and 0.1% (Velmahos et al., 2000). Reporting is variable and it is likely that many rectal injuries from such things as iatrogenic trauma, foreign body or sexual assault remain under-reported. The majority of patients are young males, with an average age of 29 reflecting the higher incidence of vehicular and violence-associated injuries in young men whereas an older age group are more likely to suffer iatrogenic injury from endoscopy (Govender and Madiba, 2010; Merlino and Reynolds, 2004). Across 39 studies, penetrating trauma accounted for 85% of rectal injuries with about 6% due to blunt mechanisms (Merlino and Reynolds, 2004). A small number are caused by other means including surgical or endoscopic mishap, obstetric trauma (Thakar and Sultan, 2003) or misadventure such as autoerotism and sexual assault (Braveman and Malangoni, 2004).

sec.title: Injury classification
sec.p: The most simple classification divides rectal trauma into intra- and extraperitoneal injury, which determines management (McGrath et al., 1998; Weinberg et al., 2006) as intraperitoneal injury is managed as a colonic injury.

In common with the other abdominal viscera, the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) has published an injury severity score for rectal trauma (Table 2) (Moore et al., 1990); this system, along with anatomical division, is helpful for planning surgical management of rectal trauma (Morken et al., 1999). sec.title: Assessment
sec.p: The assessment of rectal injury is by a combination of clinical, endoluminal and radiographic means.

sec.title: Clinical
sec.p: Victims of trauma (other than iatrogenesis) should be assessed using a recognised trauma system with the history focussing on the mechanism of injury and the type of weapon or implement used. The secondary survey should assess pelvic fracture, perineal or transpelvic penetration and rectal or urethral bleeding. Injury due to foreign body insertion rarely causes widespread trauma, but one should recognise the risk of other physical and psychological injuries, especially in cases of assault (Kann and Hicks, 2004).

Digital rectal examination (DRE) is part of the routine secondary survey but is insensitive for detecting anorectal injury with sensitivities of 37%, 33% and 5% for detection of decreased anal tone, rectal wall injury and fresh rectal bleeding, respectively (Shlamovitz et al., 2007), confirmed in a prospective US Trauma centre trial (Esposito et al., 2005) which found a high false negative rate when using DRE to diagnose spinal injury, gastrointestinal bleeding or urethral disruption. It can be difficult to ascertain whether blood is truly from the lumen or surrounding soft tissue injuries (Johnson et al., 2008).

sec.title: Sigmoidoscopy
sec.p: Rigid proctosigmoidscopy is considered mandatory, as it can reveal blood in the lumen or a rectal wall injury, as well as ascertaining the anatomy (Cleary et al., 2006; Navsaria et al., 2004). It has a higher sensitivity than DRE for detecting any rectal injury (78% v 51%) (Hargraves et al., 2009), which increases to 88% in the detection of extraperitoneal injuries. The combination of blood on DRE and positive findings on rigid sigmoidoscopy accurately predicts rectal injury in 95% and is considered the gold standard for investigating rectal trauma (MacFarlane et al., 2002; Merlino and Reynolds, 2004). However, a small study of rectal injuries in children showed that 2/24 patients had their rectal injury missed on proctoscopy compared to only 1/24 missed by CT scanning (Leaphart et al., 2006).

Flexible endoscopy may offer similar benefits to rigid sigmoidoscopy, but in the acute assessment of trauma can be difficult to organise; its use has been described using gentle insufflations only, to exclude rectal perforation when CT scanning showed ischiorectal and perirectal air after blunt pelvic fracture (Ross et al., 2001).

sec.title: Radiography
sec.p:
Abdominal radiographs are neither sensitive nor specific for colorectal injury but can reveal useful diagnostic information such as free subdiaphragmatic air and are a rapid method for confirming a retained rectal foreign body (de Stigter and Lefebvre, 2004; Jansen et al., 2008) (Figure 1). Figure 1.
Plain abdominal radiograph highlighting a retained rectal foreign body (vibrator).

CT scanning has high sensitivity and specificity for diagnosing colorectal injury and is usually advocated in trauma patients so long as it does not delay treatment. It can also accurately image the retroperitoneal space (Al-Salamah et al., 2002). The well-recognised limitation of CT scanning is the need to remove the patient from the relative safety of the Emergency Department to Radiology in many hospitals.

Common CT findings in rectal trauma are air in the pararectal spaces, metallic fragments in close proximity to the rectum, rectal wall thickening and free fluid (Johnson et al., 2008). In the military setting, CT scanning is a useful tool for rapid evaluation of the polytrauma patient allowing prioritisation of operative resources. No rectal injuries were missed but there were 2/10 false positive scans (Johnson et al., 2008).

Diagnostic yield may be increased by adding water soluble oral and rectal contrast to standard intravenous contrast (“triple contrast CT”) in penetrating trauma (Shanmuganathan et al., 2001) but is anecdotally avoided in blunt abdominal trauma due to the risk of aspiration, although evidence does not support this contention (Federle et al., 1997);if suspicion remains of rectal or bowel injury, a second CT with oral or rectal contrast as appropriate can be performed (Bondia et al., 2009).

CT scanning has further advantages in being the gold standard for identification of other organ injuries and diagnose vascular injury in proximity to rectal trauma (Vu et al., 2010); it also allows wound track evaluation which may be sufficient evidence to allow a non-operative management strategy and avoid unnecessary laparotomy (Ahmed et al., 2009).

sec.title: Management
sec.p: The goals of rectal trauma management are to arrest haemorrhage and limit sepsis, followed by rectal reconstruction and preservation of anal sphincter function; surgery concentrates around the anatomical demarcation of injury (intra- versus extraperitoneal injury) and three ongoing controversies: rectal washout, pre-sacral drainage and proximal diversion (Perry et al., 2004).

Given the strong association with other serious injuries, management should include appropriate resuscitation and prioritising life-saving procedures first. Intraperitoneal rectal injuries involve the proximal two thirds of the rectum and are sufficiently accessible to be managed as colonic injuries (Cleary et al., 2006) with direct repair or resection with primary anastomosis (Cleary et al., 2006; Lazovic et al., 2010; Maxwell and Fabian, 2003; Merlino and Reynolds, 2004). In destructive colonic injuries at high risk of dehiscence, and most military intraperitoneal rectal injuries, diversion of the faecal stream should be considered (Arthurs et al., 2006; Cleary et al., 2006; Fallon, 1992). The distal third of the rectum is difficult to access and management of injuries in this area is challenging (Cleary et al., 2006; Gonzalez et al., 2006).

Abdominoperineal resection is reserved for massive devitalising anorectal injury (Haas and Fox, 1979) and many authors would advise against such a resection at the first operation, preferring haemorrhage control and limitation of pelvic contamination, which allows a fuller evaluation at subsequent surgery and discussion of the implications of a permanent stoma with the patient.

sec.title: Faecal diversion
sec.p: Faecal diversion remains the mainstay of treatment, preventing further pelvic contamination, and can be achieved by either a proximal loop colostomy or Hartmann’s procedure, depending on the severity of the injury and the condition of the patient (Bostick et al., 1993; Burch et al., 1989; Gonzalez et al., 2006; Merlino and Reynolds, 2004). There is no difference in the efficacy of the two types of proximal diversion but reversal of a loop stoma is easier (Merlino and Reynolds, 2004). Navsaria reported a 9.9% infectious complication rate after faecal diversion in 86 cases of civilian rectal gunshot wounds, the vast majority of which were extraperitoneal – distal washout was used in only two cases (Navsaria et al., 2007). Stoma formation may be performed after diagnostic laparoscopy to exclude intraperitoneal injury without the need for laparotomy, in civilian low energy transfer GSWs at least (Ahmed et al., 2009; Navsaria et al., 2007). Distal rectal washout and pre-sacral drainage were not instituted in these studies and hospital stay was shorter compared to open proximal diversion.

sec.title: Distal rectal washout
sec.p: Distal colonic washout has been shown to reduce mortality rates in combat trauma, where the levels of energy transfer and associated injuries are higher (Morken et al., 1999). In the Vietnam War, the introduction of distal rectal washout was credited with reducing the mortality and morbidity of penetrating rectal injury from 22% and 72% to 0% and 10%, respectively, (Lavenson and Cohen, 1971). In civilian rectal trauma, the evidence is equivocal with some small case series demonstrating a significant reduction in the rates of pelvic abscesses and fistulae (Bostick et al., 1993; Shannon et al., 1988), whilst others have shown no significant difference in mortality with authors arguing that the procedure risks contaminating previously clean tissues (Govender and Madiba, 2010; Morken et al., 1999; Navsaria et al., 2004). There are no randomised trials and most authors accept that the procedure may be of benefit, especially in open pelvic fractures or destructive rectal injuries.

sec.title: Pre-sacral drainage
sec.p: Pre-sacral drainage places a drain between the coccyx and anal canal and may involve dissection through uninvolved tissue planes. A randomised trial of 48 patients showed no significant benefit regarding the reduction of pelvic sepsis (Gonzalez et al., 1998), a finding confirmed by Steinig and Boyd (1996). Burch et al.’s (1989) study of 100 patients is the only one to show drainage to significantly reduce the risk of pelvic infection. Levy et al. (1995) reported equal complication rates in patients who had drains and those who did not, although numbers in that study were small. Drainage is probably most useful in high-energy blunt trauma or if surgery is delayed (Cleary et al., 2006).

sec.title: Wound closure
sec.p: Several authors have argued that direct closure of rectal wounds is not beneficial (Burch et al., 1989; Tuggle and Huber, 1984) and many deliberate full thickness rectal tumour excision wounds are not closed and heal without complication (Bailey et al., 1992; Turner et al., 2011). Conversely, there are reports of patients undergoing primary closure of rectal wounds with good outcome, both with and without covering stomas (Levine et al., 1996; McGrath et al., 1998; Maxwell and Fabian, 2003; Thomas et al., 1990). Most surgeons agree that there is little to be lost by repairing an easily accessible rectal wound in a patient with a low overall injury burden (Levine et al., 1996) but do not support extensive pelvic dissection to access a deeply hidden injury (Levy et al., 1995; McGrath et al., 1998).

A small study has also reported no injury-associated complications without any wound-specific interventions (faecal diversion, pre-sacral diversion or rectal washout); all had a normal barium enema study by day 10 (Gonzalez et al., 2006).

sec.title: Rectal injury in open pelvic fracture
sec.p: Rectal injury caused by pelvic fracture is associated with high mortality and morbidity levels (Cleary et al., 2006). Although there are no randomised trials regarding faecal diversion or washout in these patients, most surgeons advocate both given the high rate of perineal sepsis (up to 77%) (Ferrera and Hill, 1999; Petrisora and Bhandarib, 2005) in association with meticulous debridement of devitalised soft tissues (Grotz et al., 2005).

sec.title: Management of retained foreign bodies
sec.p: The management of retained rectal foreign bodies centres around their safe removal to prevent perforation or obstruction and a multitude of methods have been described (Peet 1976; Vashist et al., 1997; Vaughan and White, 1959). The essential feature, whatever method of removal is employed, is to perform rigid sigmoidoscopy after removal to ensure no full thickness rectal injury. Any such injury is then treated in a standard fashion, which may involve a temporary colostomy with or without direct repair (Caliskan et al., 2011; Kann and Hicks, 2004).

sec.title: Complications
sec.p: Rectal trauma is associated with a high mortality rate, primarily due to concurrent injury, and Merlino and Reynolds’ (2004) cumulative analysis recorded 42/1105 deaths (3.8%), most commonly from haemorrhage (40%), associated injuries (19%) and sepsis (14%). Isolated trauma, typified by rectal foreign body insertion, also carries an associated, but lesser, mortality rate with sporadic reports of fatal perforations from both accidental injury (Caliskan et al., 2011; Waraich et al., 2007) and homicidal intent (Ikeda et al., 1991).

Morken et al. (1999) reported a 33% morbidity rate when they compared partial thickness with full thickness rectal injuries – treatment was by proximal diversion but pre-sacral drainage and washout were used only sparingly. Full thickness injuries had a three times higher rate of complications, including septic complications. They also had longer duration of colostomy and a lower rate of colostomy reversal. In Levine et al.’s (1996) study of primary repair of rectal injuries, the complications of perirectal abscess and fistulation were equally spread between groups who had diversion and no repair, no repair and diversion and diversion and repair.

In a study that including more blunt injury than most, Shatnawi and Bani-Hani (2006) described 11 patients (48%) with complications including pelvic sepsis – the majority of serious complications and the three deaths were associated with delayed presentation, more severe injury pattern (as witnessed by other organ injuries) and shock on presentation.

Merlino and Reynolds’ (2004) analysis of over 1100 rectal injuries from 39 studies revealed an overall complication rate of 24%, the single most common complication being abdominal or pelvic abscess formation (5.3%); fistula formation and generalised sepsis occurred in 2.8% and 2.3%, respectively. Pelvic abscesses may be amenable to percutaneous drainage (Gonzalez et al., 2006). Patients with pre-morbid disease and the elderly are more likely to suffer from complications as they have lower physiological reserve than their healthier counterparts (Govender and Madiba, 2010).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Civilian rectal trauma is often associated with life-threatening injury and commonly affects the young as it is mainly caused by violent crime. Initial assessment should follow ATLS guidelines and include proctosigmoidoscopy; the clinician should be aware that DRE may not elicit signs specific to rectal injury. CT scanning is sensitive and specific for rectal injury and should be performed if the patient’s condition allows. Assessment of injury caused by foreign body insertion should include a sexual history, as the patient could be at risk of sexually transmitted diseases or be a victim of sexual abuse.

The surgical management of the rectal injury depends on its anatomical location in relation to the peritoneum – intraperitoneal injuries may be treated as a colonic lesion. The evidence for extraperitoneal injury is conflicting and to some degree depends on the degree of energy transfer involved. High-energy transfer wounds, especially those from battlefield trauma, should be defunctioned with a loop colostomy being preferable. This can be constructed laparoscopically if there is no other indication for laparotomy. In civilian rectal trauma, pre-sacral drainage and distal rectal washout are probably not required but may still play a part in the management of military rectal trauma where an aggressive multi-faceted approach to this injury is warranted to minimise septic complications within the closed confines of the pelvis and maximise functional outcome.
